items.title: Two US cyber experts plead guilty to cooperating with notorious ransomware gang
items.author: Raphael Satter

items.title: Nvidia in advanced talks to buy Israel's AI21 Labs for up to $3 billion, report says
items.author: Reuters

items.title: Poland urges Brussels to probe TikTok over AI-generated content
items.author: Reuters

items.title: Warner Bros expected to reject Paramount's latest hostile bid, CNBC reports
items.author: Reuters

items.title: SoftBank has completed its $40 billion investment in OpenAI, source says
items.author: Krystal Hu

items.title: China allocates initial $8.9 billion for consumer goods trade-in scheme in 2026
items.author: Reuters

items.title: Exclusive: China mandates 50% domestic equipment rule for chipmakers
items.author: Reuters

items.title: US approves Samsung, SK Hynix chipmaking tool shipments to China for 2026, sources say
items.author: Hyunjoo Jin
items.summary:
- The U.S. Commerce Department granted Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix an annual 2026 license to import chipmaking equipment into China, creating a year-by-year export-approval system and ending the 'validated end user' exemptions on December 31. 
- After December 31, shipments will require individual U.S. export licenses; TSMC was among firms that benefited from exemptions. 
- The move reflects a continuing U.S. effort to curb China’s access to advanced American technology while Samsung and SK Hynix depend on China as a key production base for memory chips.

items.title: Meta to buy Chinese startup Manus to boost advanced AI
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - Meta to acquire Manus, a Singapore-based AI startup valued at about $2–$3 billion, with terms undisclosed. - Manus touts a general AI agent capable of autonomous decision-making with less prompting and claims competitive performance vs OpenAI's DeepResearch; backed by Beijing Butterfly Effect Technology; partners with Alibaba. - The deal signals Meta's aggressive AI strategy amid competition and Sino-U.S. tensions as Chinese firms re-domicile to Singapore; Manus raised $75M this year at a $500M valuation; investors include Benchmark, Sequoia China, ZhenFund and Tencent.

items.title: Britain's Octopus Energy to spin out Kraken at $8.65 billion valuation
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Octopus Energy will spin out Kraken as an independent company valued at about $8.65B after a funding round led by D1 Capital Partners.
- Investors include D1 Capital Partners, Origin Energy (about $140M) and Octopus Capital; Octopus will retain a 13.7% stake.
- Kraken licenses its AI OS to utilities, serving 70M accounts with >$500M contracted annual revenue, with an IPO eyed within two years.

items.title: Verisk pulls plug on $2.4 billion AccuLynx deal after FTC review delay
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Verisk terminates its $2.35 billion AccuLynx deal after the FTC review extends past the December 26 deadline.
- AccuLynx says the termination is invalid; Verisk plans to defend the position and redeem about $1.5 billion of debt raised for the acquisition.
- The move could spur 2026 capital actions like share buybacks as financing is restructured.

items.title: Nvidia takes $5 billion stake in Intel under September agreement
items.author: Reuters

items.title: Russian billionaire Potanin acquires minority stake in cloud provider Selectel
items.author: Reuters

items.title: Two Chinese flagship ETFs launch in Thailand as China lures foreign investors
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- China Asset Management launched two flagship ETFs in Thailand as depository receipts, giving Thai investors access to CSI300 and STAR 50 blue-chip stocks (DRs 510330.SS, 588000.SS).
- DRs trade in real-time in Thai baht with capital gains tax exemptions and no overseas accounts; InnovestX Securities aided issuance and market-making.
- This signals deeper China–Thailand financial integration under Belt and Road; CSI300 up ~18% and STAR50 up ~36% this year, with ongoing ChinaAMC initiatives in Thailand.

items.title: South Korea's L&F slashes value of battery material supply deal with Tesla
items.author: Hyunjoo Jin, Heekyong Yang

items.title: SoftBank nears deal for data center investment firm DigitalBridge, Bloomberg News reports
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- SoftBank is reportedly in advanced talks to acquire DigitalBridge (DBRG.N) per Bloomberg News citing unnamed sources.
- A deal could be announced as soon as Monday, though Reuters has not independently verified the report.
- SoftBank trades as 9984.T and DigitalBridge trades as DBRG.N.

items.title: China's LandSpace gears up to take on Elon Musk and SpaceX
items.author: Eduardo Baptista
items.summary:
- LandSpace conducted China's first test of a reusable rocket (Zhuque-3) at Jiuquan, but the flight ended in a crash as the booster did not perform a landing burn about 3 km from the ground.
- The company aims to be a major reusable launcher to support Beijing's plan for large satellite constellations and is pursuing an IPO to fund future projects.
- Designers say Zhuque-3 is SpaceX-inspired with a Falcon 9–like architecture, stainless steel and methalox propulsion, while Musk notes Starship concepts are being applied in a different league.

items.title: Coupang announces $1.18 billion compensation to South Korean users for data leak
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Coupang unveiled a compensation plan totaling 1.69 trillion won (~$1.18 billion) for about 33.7 million affected accounts, granting eligible customers 50,000 won vouchers usable only on Coupang services.
- Critics say the vouchers amount to marketing tactics that constrain restitution, with lawmakers and consumer groups accusing Coupang of downplaying the breach.
- Parliament set two days of hearings; founder Kim Bom apologized but will not attend due to prior commitments, and the report notes the exchange rate used: $1 = 1,434.60 won.

items.title: Louis Gerstner, former IBM CEO who revitalized 'Big Blue,' dies at 83
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Former IBM CEO Louis Gerstner Jr. died at 83; as the first outsider to run IBM (1993–2002), he steered a turnaround toward services and lifted the stock significantly.
- After IBM, he chaired the Carlyle Group until 2008 and wrote Who Says Elephants Can't Dance while serving on boards including American Express and Caterpillar.
- He championed public education with IBM technology initiatives and established the Gerstner Foundations for education, environment and social services.

items.title: More Israeli tech workers want to relocate abroad, report says
items.author: Steven Scheer
items.summary: - 53% of companies saw more relocation requests amid the ongoing conflict, risking local tech leadership.\n- The sector accounts for ~20% of GDP, 15% of jobs, and >50% of exports, with Microsoft, Intel, Nvidia, Amazon, Meta and Apple operating in Israel.\n- War disruptions push some multinationals to shift investments; rising executive relocation demand underscores the need for regulatory and geopolitical stability.

items.title: Amazon halts plans for drone delivery in Italy
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Amazon will not pursue commercial drone delivery in Italy after a strategic review, citing an unfavorable regulatory framework for its longer-term objectives.
- The company noted progress with regulators and said it had completed initial drone delivery tests in December 2024 in San Salvo, Abruzzo.
- ENAC called the decision unexpected; the current Italian regulatory environment is not conducive to continuing the project.

items.title: Coupang founder Kim Bom apologises for data leak, pledges compensation
items.author: Heejin Kim
items.summary:
- Kim Bom apologized for the data breach, said Coupang is cooperating with authorities and will announce a compensation plan for South Korean customers soon; all leaked data has been restored.
- Only 3,000 of 33 million customers were affected; data found on a suspect's PC but not transferred or sold; Coupang pledges reforms and investments to prevent future breaches.
- Lawmakers consider action amid criticism of the US-based chair and ongoing government investigation.

items.title: TSMC says some facilities evacuated after quake
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Some TSMC facilities in Hsinchu science park triggered evacuation criteria after the earthquake.
- The company is conducting outdoor evacuations and headcounts per emergency procedures to ensure safety.
- Work-safety systems across all facilities remain operational and monitoring continues.

items.title: Waymo's San Francisco outage raises doubts over robotaxi readiness during crises
items.author: Abhirup Roy

items.title: China issues drafts rules to regulate AI with human-like interaction
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Draft rules target AI services that simulate personalities and emotional interactions to tighten safety and ethics oversight.
- Providers must warn about excessive use, intervene on addiction, and ensure safety across the product lifecycle (algorithm review, data security).
- Prohibited: content endangering security, rumors, violence, or obscenity; providers must assess user states and act on extreme or addictive behavior.

items.title: China revises aviation law to regulate drones, tighten safety rules
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Revisions require airworthiness certification for most unmanned aircraft and assign a unique product ID to each drone, effective July 1, 2025.
- Micro and small drones remain exempt; medium and large drones must obtain CAAC certification as the regime tightens low-altitude drone activity.
- The overhaul aims to close regulatory gaps as drone logistics expand, with major players like DJI and EHang potentially affected and drone deliveries growing.

items.title: New York to require social media platforms to display mental health warnings
items.author: Jasper Ward
items.summary: - New York will require platforms with infinite scroll or auto-play to display warning labels about potential harm to young users’ mental health, with penalties up to $5,000 per violation. - The measure applies to conduct in New York and lets the attorney general pursue civil penalties; it follows other states and a 2023 Surgeon General advisory. - TikTok, Snap, Meta, and Alphabet did not comment; Australia recently banned under-16s as part of global concern over youth mental health.

items.title: Atos to sell Latin American businesses to Brazil's Semantix
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Atos signed a binding agreement to sell its Latin American operations to Brazilian tech firm Semantix, covering about 2,800 employees across Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Peru and Uruguay.
- Financial terms were undisclosed, with a closing expected in coming months, as part of Atos' restructuring after 2024 troubles that saw roughly €2.1 billion of debt trimmed and banks/bondholders gaining stake.
- The deal is in line with Atos' asset-sale–driven turnaround strategy.

items.title: China eases IPO rules for firms developing reusable rockets
items.author: Eduardo Baptista
items.summary:
- Shanghai's STAR Market fast-tracks listings for reusable-rocket developers, exempting profitability and revenue tests if milestones (including at least one orbital launch) are met.
- The change builds on June guidance to broaden access for pre-profit innovators and aims to narrow the gap with SpaceX via easier capital access.
- LandSpace's Zhuque-3 has performed a full reusable-flight test; booster recovery is not required to qualify yet, with recovery plans by mid-2026 and priority to national missions; guidelines take effect immediately.

items.title: Wingtech chairman says it must take back control of Nexperia, state media reports
items.author: Reuters

items.title: South Korea charges 10 over alleged chip technology leak to China's CXMT
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Ten people indicted in South Korea for allegedly leaking memory chip technology to CXMT, aiding China's AI-focused HBM development.
- A former Samsung researcher copied hundreds of DRAM steps by hand; CXMT rebuilt its flow and obtained DRAM tech via an SK Hynix supplier.
- Prosecutors say the leak cost Samsung trillions of won; CXMT plans a Shanghai listing (~$42B) after DDR5 and 10-nm DRAM milestones.

items.title: China launches venture capital funds to invest in 'hard technology', state media report
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Three state-backed venture-capital funds with over 150 billion yuan in planned capital, per CCTV on Dec 26.
- Funds will back early-stage startups valued below 500 million yuan, with individual investments capped at 50 million yuan.
- Target sectors: integrated circuits, quantum tech, biomedicine, brain–computer interfaces, aerospace and other hard technologies; internet services deemed soft tech and excluded.

items.title: China says it hopes firms seek lawful, balanced solutions over TikTok deal
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - The Chinese commerce ministry urged that TikTok handover solutions comply with Chinese laws and balance all parties' interests. - ByteDance signed binding agreements transferring control of TikTok's U.S. operations to a consortium including Oracle, aiming to avert a U.S. ban. - China called on the U.S. to cooperate in a fair, open, transparent, and non-discriminatory environment to support continued operation of Chinese firms in the U.S.

items.title: Foreign-branded phone shipments in China more than doubled on year in Nov, CAICT data shows
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- China's total mobile phone shipments in November 2025 reached 30.16 million units, up 1.9% YoY per CAICT.
- Foreign-branded shipments rose 128.4% YoY to 6.93 million units, with Apple iPhones included among foreign brands.
- The data signal increasing penetration of foreign brands in China's smartphone market.

items.title: Nvidia will license Groq tech, hire its executives
items.author: Stephen Nellis

items.title: China's LandSpace hopes to complete rocket recovery in mid-2026
items.author: Eduardo Baptista

items.title: How a Silicon Valley dealmaker charmed Trump and gave Intel a lifeline
items.author: Max Cherney, Jeffrey Dastin
items.summary:
- Tan met Trump in the Oval Office, leading to a government commitment to invest billions for a near-10% stake in Intel and a reshoring narrative.
- The package included a $5.7B cash infusion and a subsequent $5B Nvidia partnership, making the U.S. government Intel’s largest shareholder.
- Intel restructured under Tan with an engineering-led culture and closer government engagement to defend against rivals like TSMC.

items.title: Italy watchdog orders Meta to halt WhatsApp terms barring rival AI chatbots
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- AGCM orders Meta to suspend WhatsApp terms that could bar rival AI chatbots as it probes potential abuse of a dominant position.
- Meta says the decision is flawed and will appeal; the probe began in July and was widened in November to cover WhatsApp Business terms.
- EU antitrust regulators are conducting a parallel inquiry, coordinating with the European Commission, amid US pushback and criticism from the Trump administration.

items.title: Waymo to update software after San Francisco power outage snarls self-driving vehicles
items.author: David Shepardson
items.summary:
- Waymo will roll fleet-wide software updates to add power-outage context and help vehicles navigate more decisively during outages.
- Emergency-response protocols and confirmation checks at dark intersections will be refined to reduce congestion and improve safety.
- Regulators are reviewing the SF incident; Waymo recently recalled software over Texas school-bus violations amid a broader probe.

items.title: Fleet management firm Motive Technologies reveals revenue growth in US IPO paperwork
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Files for a U.S. IPO on NYSE (MTVE); nine-month revenue $327.3M and net loss $138.5M through Sept 30, versus $268.9M revenue and $113.9M loss a year earlier.
- SF-based AI-powered fleet manager serving logistics, construction, energy and manufacturing; clients include Halliburton, KONE, Komatsu, NBCUniversal and Maersk; founded 2013.
- Underwriters JPMorgan, Citigroup, Jefferies and Barclays; market backdrop cites 2025 momentum tempered by tariffs, shutdown risks and AI stock selloff.

items.title: Apple to allow third-party app stores in Brazil to settle iOS case with regulator
items.author: Reuters

items.title: US judge blocks Texas app store age law meant to protect children
items.author: Mike Scarcella
items.summary:
- A federal judge blocked Texas's App Store Accountability Act, finding likely First Amendment issues and delaying its January start.
- The Computer & Communications Industry Association sued to stop the law, arguing it would curb app stores' and users' rights.
- Texas plans to appeal; the ruling reflects broader concerns about youth online safety and parental controls.

items.title: Trump's AI hiring campaign draws interest from 25,000 hopefuls
items.author: Courtney Rozen

items.title: US delays announcement of China chip tariffs until 2027
items.author: Alexandra Alper, Akash Sriram

items.title: ServiceNow to buy Armis for $7.75 billion as AI-fueled cyber risks surge
items.author: Kritika Lamba, Jaspreet Singh

items.title: China's commerce ministry urges US to drop drone supplier ban
items.author: Reuters

items.title: China's LandSpace completes 'tutoring' process ahead of Shanghai IPO
items.author: Eduardo Baptista
items.summary:
- LandSpace completed the STAR Market 'tutoring' phase with regulator, guided by state-backed CICC, for a potential 2026 Shanghai listing.
- The STAR Market targets pre-profit frontier tech; LandSpace seeks funds to advance its Zhuque-3 reusable-rocket program to rival SpaceX.
- Zhuque-3's December 2025 full reusable rocket test ended in a landing crash; public funding could accelerate iteration as SpaceX reportedly planned an IPO in 2026.

items.title: Paramount's new offer for Warner Bros is not sufficient, major investor says
items.author: Ross Kerber, Dawn Kopecki

items.title: Insight: AI data centers are forcing dirty ‘peaker’ power plants back into service
items.author: Laila Kearney

items.title: WhatsApp calls out restrictions in Russia after reported slowdown
items.author: Alexander Marrow, Andrew Osborn
